body: @marcphilipp thanks for raising it. We are almost ready to release 3.21.0 which will contain ByteBuddy 1.11.15.

I'm glad to hear it. ðŸ‘ 

Do you publish snapshots somewhere so I could check with those?

No, unfortunately we don't publish snapshots, but our CI runs with JDK 18-ea and we _should_ have test cases like that :-)

I'm wondering if this issue has been fixed before we added JDK 18-ea to our CI. Do you know the version of ByteBuddy that fixed it? I didn't catch it by quickly reading the changelog.
No, I don't know which version of ByteBuddy fixed it.

I tried executing all tests of 3.20.2 codebase using JDK 18.ea.14, but nothing failed.

@marcphilipp would you have the chance to build the latest AssertJ locally and verify that everything works? Otherwise, how can I reproduce your issue?

I built a snapshot locally and now I'm getting a different error:
```
Failures (1):
  JUnit Jupiter:EngineTestKitAllEventsDemo:verifyAllJupiterEvents()
    MethodSource [className = 'example.testkit.EngineTestKitAllEventsDemo', methodName = 'verifyAllJupiterEvents', methodParameterTypes = '']
    => java.lang.IllegalAccessError: superinterface check failed: class org.assertj.core.internal.bytebuddy.utility.Invoker$Dispatcher (in unnamed module @0x16943e88) cannot access class org.assertj.core.internal.bytebuddy.utility.Invoker (in module org.assertj.core) because module org.assertj.core does not export org.assertj.core.internal.bytebuddy.utility to unnamed module @0x16943e88
       java.base/java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass1(Native Method)
       java.base/java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass(ClassLoader.java:1012)
       org.assertj.core@3.21.0-SNAPSHOT/org.assertj.core.internal.bytebuddy.utility.dispatcher.JavaDispatcher$DynamicClassLoader.invoker(JavaDispatcher.java:1309)
       org.assertj.core@3.21.0-SNAPSHOT/org.assertj.core.internal.bytebuddy.utility.dispatcher.JavaDispatcher$InvokerCreationAction.run(JavaDispatcher.java:437)
       org.assertj.core@3.21.0-SNAPSHOT/org.assertj.core.internal.bytebuddy.utility.dispatcher.JavaDispatcher$InvokerCreationAction.run(JavaDispatcher.java:430)
       java.base/java.security.AccessController.doPrivileged(AccessController.java:318)
       org.assertj.core@3.21.0-SNAPSHOT/org.assertj.core.internal.bytebuddy.utility.dispatcher.JavaDispatcher.doPrivileged(JavaDispatcher.java)
       org.assertj.core@3.21.0-SNAPSHOT/org.assertj.core.internal.bytebuddy.utility.dispatcher.JavaDispatcher.<clinit>(JavaDispatcher.java:72)
       org.assertj.core@3.21.0-SNAPSHOT/org.assertj.core.internal.bytebuddy.description.type.TypeDescription$ForLoadedType.<clinit>(TypeDescription.java:8378)
       org.assertj.core@3.21.0-SNAPSHOT/org.assertj.core.internal.bytebuddy.description.type.TypeDescription.<clinit>(TypeDescription.java:65)
       [...]
```

I'll see if I can extract that test into a standalone reproducer project.

Why `org.assertj.core.internal.bytebuddy.utility.Invoker$Dispatcher` would be "in unnamed module @0x16943e88" while `org.assertj.core.internal.bytebuddy.utility.Invoker` is "in module org.assertj.core" is beyond me.

@sormuras Any idea?
I'm looking into this - but it seems to be something that @raphw might be able to resolve with ... one look, click, keystroke, right Raphael?

Half off-topic observation: Java modules with version information compiled into their descriptors are awesome!

Seeing 2 different version used in this thread. And https://twitter.com/sormuras/status/1437370883786657794

Is the `Xyz$Dispatcher` generated at runtime? If yes, does ByteBuddy support something similar to `--default-module-for-created-files` option of the `javac` tool and if it does, does AssertJ set an appropriate value?

> --default-module-for-created-files module-name
> Specifies the fallback target module for files created by annotation processors, if none is specified or inferred.
Yes, it is. The dispatcher is in an isolated class loader by design to avoid exposing module privileges. Java 18 still requires -Dnet.bytebuddy.experimental=true in this old version.
@marcphilipp did you try to set `-Dnet.bytebuddy.experimental=true` also with the snapshot?

> did you try to set `-Dnet.bytebuddy.experimental=true` also with the snapshot?

I did and I now also tried with 18.ea.14 and the GA version of JDK 17. Both fail when using the latest snapshot.

I pushed my experiments to a [branch](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/tree/marc/assertj-reproducer). To run it locally run `./mvn clean install` on this repo and then the following command on my branch of the junit5 repo:
```
./gradlew -Dplatform.tooling.support.tests.enabled=true :platform-tooling-support-tests:test --tests ModularUserGuideTests -PjavaToolchainVersion=17
```

`ModularUserGuideTests` is a test that calls java to run tests using the module path:
https://ge.junit.org/s/3x62y7wmrsgmw/tests/:platform-tooling-support-tests:test/platform.tooling.support.tests.ModularUserGuideTests/runTestsFromUserGuideWithinModularBoundaries(Path)?anchor=e30&focused-execution=1#L1

I see, the problem is the shading. The Invoker class needs to be exported. Ideally, assertj would not shade Byte Buddy, it changes its assumed properties for running as a module. I'll see if I can do something in Byte Buddy to improve shading convenience, but I'd mainly recommend to not shade it.

Argh... it's almost always shady shading! Where are my shades?! ðŸ•¶

See this list for further shading-related ... issues: https://github.com/sormuras/modules/blob/main/doc/suspicious/impostor-modules.md
The problem is that BB assumes that the package is exported. I'd need to add a check to see if this is not the case, to open the package to the class loader's unnamed package.

@raphw not sure if there is anything that we could add to the shading exclusions to make it work. 

For example, some time ago I excluded `net.bytebuddy.experimental` as the expected property was converted to `org.assertj.core.internal.bytebuddy.experimental`, which is confusing for anyone trying to enable BB experimental features.

https://github.com/assertj/assertj-core/blob/48ed152ca335612fffb7182646cbe2c13a026806/pom.xml#L361-L363

See also https://github.com/jqno/equalsverifier/issues/339#issuecomment-682157281.

This might be a detail worth adding to the ByteBuddy documentation as shading could be a common use case.
